unnormalised: The world of Indian sports holds its breath this week as key injury updates across cricket and kabaddi threaten to reshuffle team dynamics and impact upcoming tournaments. From the hallowed grounds of the Eden Gardens to the sandy kabaddi arenas, athletes are battling against time and recovery.
normalised: The world of Indian sports holds its breath this week as key injury updates across cricket and kabaddi threaten to reshuffle team dynamics and impact upcoming tournaments. From the hallowed grounds of the Eden Gardens to the sandy kabaddi arenas, athletes are battling against time and recovery.

unnormalised: In cricket, the biggest news revolves around opening batsman, Prithvi Shaw. Reports emerging from the National Cricket Academy (NCA) in Bengaluru suggest Shaw is still struggling with the knee injury sustained during the Ranji Trophy quarter-final against Karnataka last month. While initial assessments estimated a six-week recovery period, sources close to the NCA indicate rehabilitation is progressing slower than anticipated. This casts serious doubt on his availability for the upcoming T20 series against Australia, a major setback for the Men in Blue. Team physio, Dr. Rajesh Kumar, remained tight-lipped, only stating that Shaw is "undergoing intensive therapy and his progress is being closely monitored."

unnormalised: Adding to the woes, fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah is also facing renewed concerns. After a long layoff due to a stress fracture in his back, Bumrah made a promising return to domestic cricket but reportedly experienced discomfort during a recent practice session. While the severity is still unclear, it raises questions about his workload management and his readiness for the gruelling Test series against South Africa later this year. Some are drawing parallels to the "Chak De! India" storyline, highlighting the importance of prioritizing player health over immediate glory.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, in the Pro Kabaddi League (PKL) circuit, star raider Pardeep Narwal of the UP Yoddhas is battling a shoulder injury he sustained during the match against Patna Pirates last week. Initial scans reveal a grade 2 tear in his rotator cuff. The Yoddhas management has confirmed that Narwal will be out of action for at least 3 weeks. This is a significant blow to their playoff hopes as Narwal contributes heavily to their raiding points.

unnormalised: Elsewhere, young kabaddi sensation, Rahul Chaudhari from Jaipur Pink Panthers, is nursing a minor ankle sprain picked up during training. The team management expects him to be fit for their next game against Puneri Paltan. He is currently undergoing physiotherapy and rehabilitation at the Sawai Mansingh Stadium in Jaipur.
